name: General Psychology
description:
Principles and basic concepts of psychology. The empirical study of individual
behavior including perception, cognition, development, personality, social
interactions and the biological underpinnings of behavior.

name: Eval Rsch Methods
description:
Surveys applications of research methods to the evaluation of social programs,
primarily emphasizing methodological issues, e.g., research design and data
collection; uses of evaluation research are also discussed and placed in
theoretical context. Participation in an evaluation project.
prereq: SOC 001 or SOC 002 or SOC 003 recommended; SOC 046A and SOC 046B recommended.

name: Short Calculus
description:
Limits; differentiation of algebraic functions; analytic geometry;
applications, in particular to maxima and minima problems.
prereq:
Two years of high school algebra, plane geometry, plane trigonometry, and
satisfying the Mathematics Placement Requirement.

name: Elementary Latin
description:
Introduction to basic grammar and vocabulary and development of translation
skills with emphasis on Latin to English.

name: Short Calculus
description:
Limits; differentiation of algebraic functions; analytic geometry;
applications, in particular to maxima and minima problems.
prereq:
Two years of high school algebra, plane geometry, plane trigonometry, and
satisfying the Mathematics Placement Requirement.

name: Physical Activities
description:
Physical Education Activities classes offered in the following areas:
aquatics, personal fitness, martial arts, individual sports, and team sports.
These academic classes are instructional rather than recreational and are
intended to improve activity specific skills and knowledge.

name: First-Year Seminar
description:
Investigation of a special topic through shared readings, discussions, written
assignments, term papers, and special activities (such as fieldwork, site
visits, laboratory work, etc.). Emphasis placed upon student participation in
learning. Students may take more than one First-Year Seminar, but may not take
more than one in any given quarter.

name: Intro to NA Lit
description:
Intensive focus on analysis of Native American literary texts, with frequent
writing assignments to develop critical thinking and composition skills.

name: Intro to NA Lit
description:
Intensive focus on analysis of Native American literary texts, with frequent
writing assignments to develop critical thinking and composition skills.

name: Elementary Accounting
description:
Basic concepts of accounting; interpreting and using financial statements;
understanding accounting principles.

name: General Physics
description: Continuation of PHY 007B.

name: Criminology
description:
Sociological analysis of criminal behavior in relation to social structure and
the criminalization process.

name: First-Year Seminar
description:
Investigation of a special topic through shared readings, discussions, written
assignments, term papers, and special activities (such as fieldwork, site
visits, laboratory work, etc.). Emphasis placed upon student participation in
learning. Students may take more than one First-Year Seminar, but may not take
more than one in any given quarter.

name: Introductory Mycology
description:
Systematics, ecology, evolution, and morphology of fungi. Importance of fungi
to humans.

name: University Jazz Band
description:
Open to students in any major. rehearsal, study, and performance of jazz band
music and full variety of jazz band style, including swing, be-bob, and
contemporary jazz styles.
prereq: Consent of Instructor. Admission by audition.

name: Calculus
description:
Functions, limits, continuity. Slope and derivative. Differentiation of
algebraic and transcendental functions. Applications to motion, natural
growth, graphing, extrema of a function. Differentials. L'Hopital's rule.
prereq:
Two years of high school algebra, plane geometry, plane trigonometry, and
analytical geometry, and satisfying the Mathematics Placement Requirement.

name: University Symphony
description:
Open to any student in the University whose proficiency meets the requirements
of concert performance. Sight-reading, rehearsal and performance of music from
the orchestral literature.
prereq: Consent of Instructor. Admission by audition.

name: Research Conference
description:
Research findings and methods in neurobiology, physiology, and/or behavior.
Presentation and discussion of research by faculty and students.
prereq:
NPB 199 { can be concurrent }; and Consent of Instructor. Upper division
standing in Neurobiology, Physiology, and Behavior or related biological
science; NPB 199 required concurrently.

name: Intro Microbiology Lab
description:
Introduction to principles and laboratory methods employed in working with
microorganisms. Designed for students requiring microbiology for professional
school admission. May be taught abroad.

name: Intermed Musicianship
description:
Melodic, rhythmic, and harmonic materials of Western music. Includes sight
singing, explanations, drills, melodic/rhythmic/harmonic dictations, and
listening analysis.
prereq:
MUS 016C; MUS 007A { can be concurrent }; Or demonstrate required proficiency
level on diagnostic exam.

name: Calculus
description:
Functions, limits, continuity. Slope and derivative. Differentiation of
algebraic and transcendental functions. Applications to motion, natural
growth, graphing, extrema of a function. Differentials. L'Hopital's rule.
prereq:
Two years of high school algebra, plane geometry, plane trigonometry, and
analytical geometry, and satisfying the Mathematics Placement Requirement.

name: Systemic Physiology Lab
description:
Selected experiments to illustrate functional characteristics of organ systems
discussed in NPB 101.

name: Princ of Epi in Nutr
description:
Introduction to epidemiology as it relates to the field of nutrition,
including study design, principles of epidemiologic inference, criteria for
causality, and interpreting measures of disease risk.

name: Elementary Hindi/Urdu I
description:
Introduction to Devanagari Script through development of all language skills
in a cultural context with emphasis on communicative proficiency.

name: Directed Gp Study
description: Directed group study.

name: First-Year Seminar
description:
Investigation of a special topic through shared readings, discussions, written
assignments, term papers, and special activities (such as fieldwork, site
visits, laboratory work, etc.). Emphasis placed upon student participation in
learning. Students may take more than one First-Year Seminar, but may not take
more than one in any given quarter.

name: Global Humanities
description:
Introduction to humanities topics and methodologies; analysis of major
figures, works, and genres in world arts and literatures, with emphasis on
relationships between history, society, and culture.

name: Plants & Society
description:
Dependence of human societies on plant and plant products. Plants as resources
for food, fiber, health, enjoyment and environmental services. Sustainable
uses of plants for food production, raw materials, bioenergy, and
environmental conservation. Global population growth and future food supplies.

name: General Physics
description:
Introduction to general principles and analytical methods used in physics for
students majoring in a biological science.

name: US History: 1917-1945
description:
America's emergence as a world power, the business culture of the 1920s, the
New Deal and World War II. Emphasis on such issues as government regulation of
the economy, welfare capitalism, and class, racial, ethnic, and gender
conflicts.

name: Amer Natl Govt
description:
Survey of American national government, including the constitutional system,
political culture, parties, elections, the presidency, Congress, and the
courts.

name: Infancy & Early Childhd
description:
Biological, social, and cultural influences in the psychological growth and
development of children, prenatal through age six. Two observations of
preschool children required.
prereq:
PSC 001; (BIS 002A or BIS 010 or BIS 001A or BIS 010V) or MCB 010 or NPB 010
or NPB 012 or MIC 010

name: Internship
description: Professional field experience in landscape architecture.
prereq: Consent of Instructor. Senior standing in Landscape Architecture.

name: First-Year Seminar
description:
Investigation of a special topic through shared readings, discussions, written
assignments, term papers, and special activities (such as fieldwork, site
visits, laboratory work, etc.). Emphasis placed upon student participation in
learning. Students may take more than one First-Year Seminar, but may not take
more than one in any given quarter.

name: Western Civ
description: Development of Western Civilization from the 18th century to the present.

name: Intro to NA Lit
description:
Intensive focus on analysis of Native American literary texts, with frequent
writing assignments to develop critical thinking and composition skills.

name: Comp Vert Organology
description:
Functional anatomy of major organ systems in vertebrates. Each system examined
from cellular to gross level in fish, birds, and mammals. Emphasis on how
differentiated cell types are integrated into tissues and organs to perform
diverse physiological functions.

name: Intro to NA Lit
description:
Intensive focus on analysis of Native American literary texts, with frequent
writing assignments to develop critical thinking and composition skills.

name: Judicial Politics
description:
Politics of judicial policy making, issues surrounding constitutional
interpretation and decision making, prerequisite for courses on the politics
of constitutional law.

name: Food Processing
description:
Application of the conservation of mass and energy to food processing.
Elements of engineering thermodynamics, fluid mechanics, heat and mass
transfer. Quantitative analysis through problem solving and simulation.
prereq:
PHY 007A; PHY 007B; PHY 007C; MAT 016A; MAT 016B; MAT 016C; Or equivalent to
PHY 007 series or MAT 016 series.

name: Applied Stat for Bio Sci
description:
Descriptive statistics, probability, sampling distributions, estimation,
hypothesis testing, contingency tables, ANOVA, regression; implementation of
statistical methods using computer package.

name: Elementary Algebra
description:
Basic concepts of algebra, including polynomials, factoring, equations,
graphs, and inequalities. Offered only if sufficient number of students
enroll.

name: Social & Personal Devel
description:
Social and personality development of children, infancy through adolescence.
Topics include the development of personality, achievement motivation, self-
understanding, sex-role identity, and antisocial behavior. Emphasis on the
interface between biological and social factors.

name: Intro Environ Design
description:
Introduction to the role of design professionals in contributing to the built
environment at a range of scales. Introduction to basic methods used by design
professionals to evaluate, design, plan, and manage landscapes and the built
environment.

name: Internship Pub Aff
description:
Supervised internship and study in political, governmental, or related
organizations.
prereq:
POL 192A; enrollment dependent on availability of intern positions with
highest priority assigned to students with Political Science-Public Service
major; upper division standing.

name: Adulthood & Aging
description:
Development during early, middle, and late adulthood; biological, cognitive,
and psycho-social aspects of adult development. Emphasis on normative patterns
of development which characterize "successful aging."

name: Readings in Newspapers
description:
Fourth-year level reading of newspaper and magazine reports, articles, and
editorials on domestic and international affairs relating to contemporary
Japan.
prereq: JPN 113; Or the equivalent language proficiency.

name: Organic Crop Prod Pract
description:
Principles and practices of organic production of annual crops. Including
organic crops, soil, and pest management, cover cropping, composting, seeding,
transplanting, irrigation, harvesting and marketing.

name: Plant Physiology
description:
Plant cell as a functional unit. The processes of absorption, movement, and
utilization of water and minerals. Water loss, translocation, photosynthesis,
respiration.
prereq:
(BIS 002A, BIS 002B, BIS 002C); (CHE 008B { can be concurrent } or CHE 118B {
can be concurrent }); PHY 007C { can be concurrent }; PLB 105 recommended.

name: American Masters
description:
Overview of American concert music by master composers from Charles Ives to
the present. Lectures, discussion/guided listening sections, and selected
readings. For non-majors.
prereq: MUS 010 or MUS 003A; or Consent of Instructor.

name: Elem Human Physiology
description:
Introduction to physiology for non-science majors. Includes basic cell
physiology and survey of major organ systems and how they function in
homeostasis and human health.

name: Physical Geology Lab
description:
Introduction to classification and recognition of minerals and rocks and to
interpretation of topographic and geologic maps and aerial photographs.

name: Genes Nutrients Health
description:
Biochemical, physiological, genetic, and nutritional causes of important
medical problems such as obesity, anorexia, heart disease and diabetes.
prereq: BIS 001A or BIS 002A; or Consent of Instructor.

name: Production Lab
description: Laboratory experience in quantity food production and service.

name: Thermo & Stat Physics
description:
Introduction to classical and quantum statistical mechanics and their
connections with thermodynamics. Theory is developed for the ideal gas model
and simple magnetic models and then extended to studies of solids, quantum
fluids, and chemical equilibria.

name: Academic Literacies
description:
Composition, the essay, paragraph structure, diction, and related topics.
Frequent writing assignments.

name: Human Rights
description:
Introduction to the interdisciplinary study of the origins, evolution, denial
and protection of Human Rights.

name: Plant Genetics
description:
Basic principles of transmission genetics, cytogenetics, population and
quantitative genetics, and molecular genetics. Practical aspects of genetic
crosses and analysis of segregating populations.
prereq: BIS 001A or BIS 002A; or Consent of Instructor.

name: Intro Doc Studies
description:
Recent evolution of the documentary. The personal essay film; found-
footage/appropriation work; non-linear, multi-media forms; spoken word;
storytelling; oral history recordings; and other examples of documentary
expression.

name: Health Psychology
description:
Psychological factors influencing health and illness. Topics include stress
and coping, personality and health, symptom perception and reporting, heart
disease, cancer, compliance, and health maintenance and promotion.

name: Topics Gender Studies
description:
In-depth examination of a women's studies topic related to the research
interests of the instructor.

name: Advancd Multiling Wrtng
description:
Reading and writing source/research-based texts for academic purposes.
Suitable for students whose primary home language was not English.

name: Technical Writing
description:
Communicating effectively about technology and other technical subjects to
varied audiences for varied purposes. Suitable for students entering
professions that require communicating technical information to subject matter
experts, managers, technicians, and non-specialists.

name: Intro Gender Studies
description:
Introduction to interdisciplinary, critical gender studies. Addresses the
emergence of women‚Äôs, gender and feminist studies internationally, its links
to women‚Äôs movements, and its influence within the various arts, humanities
and social science disciplines.

name: Academic Literacies
description:
Composition, the essay, paragraph structure, diction, and related topics.
Frequent writing assignments.

and beyond the University. Different writing modes, including narrative,
analysis, explanation, argument, critique.
prereq: UWP 001 or ENL 003; Or the equivalent and upper division standing.

name: Culture & Health
description:
Analysis of how socio-cultural factors shape illness experience. Evaluation of
how certain conditions come to be understood as health conditions; illness
identities and biographies; doctor-patient interactions; biomedical cultures;
and how race, ethnicity, and gender shape health practices.
prereq: SOC 001, SOC 002, SOC 003, or SOC 006 recommended.

name: Physical Activities
description:
Physical Education Activities classes offered in the following areas:
aquatics, personal fitness, martial arts, individual sports, and team sports.
These academic classes are instructional rather than recreational and are
intended to improve activity specific skills and knowledge.

name: Int Fin Accounting I
description:
Begin to develop expertise in the accounting for assets and introduce analysis
of financial statements.

name: Pol Global Ineq
description:
Analysis of current economic and political international relations resulting
from a long standing division of the global system into rich and poor regions.

name: Analytical Mechanic
instructor: Manuel Calderon De La Barca Sanchez
description:
Principles and applications of Newtonian mechanics; introduction to Lagrange‚Äôs
and Hamilton‚Äôs equations
prereq:
(PHY 009B C or better, PHY 009C C or better, PHY 009D C or better); (MAT 021D
C or better, MAT 022A C or better, MAT 022B C or better); Or consent of
department for any of the courses.

name: Directed Group Study
description: Directed group study.

name: Physical Activities
description:
Physical Education Activities classes offered in the following areas:
aquatics, personal fitness, martial arts, individual sports, and team sports.
These academic classes are instructional rather than recreational and are
intended to improve activity specific skills and knowledge.

name: Facilitating Learning
description:
STEM Learning Assistant Seminar. Theoretical and practical issues of effective
teaching in discussion/labs: student-centered, active, cooperative learning
environments, responsive teaching, and differentiated classroom instruction.

name: Mnging & Using Info Tech
description:
Develop an analytical framework to manage and monitor business systems
concerned with operational, human, and organizational interactions.
Introduction to computer hardware, systems software, and information systems.
Management of information technology and the impact of information systems on
modern management.

name: Religion & Language
description:
Basic toolkit for studying religious discourse in a variety of traditions.
Concentration on the sacred and profane, the wondrous and ordinary, and the
mystical and reasonable.

name: Writing in Sociology
description:
Advanced instruction in writing and practice in effective styles of
communication in Sociology and related academic and professional fields.
prereq: UWP 001 or ENL 003; Or the equivalent and upper division standing.

name: Self & Society
description:
Exploration of how self and identity are formed and transformed by
socialization and social interaction in relation to roles, groups,
institutions, power, and social change. Consideration of how people make
decisions, fall in love, and come to blows.

name: Intro Multiling Writing
description:
Reading and writing paragraphs and short multi-paragraph texts for academic
purposes. Suitable for students whose primary home language was not English.

name: Advanced Composition
description:
Instruction in advanced principles of expository writing. Writing tasks within
and beyond the University. Different writing modes, including narrative,
analysis, explanation, argument, critique.
prereq: UWP 001 or ENL 003; Or the equivalent and upper division standing.

name: Academic Literacies
description:
Composition, the essay, paragraph structure, diction, and related topics.
Frequent writing assignments.

name: Probability Theory
description:
Fundamental concepts of probability theory, discrete and continuous random
variables, standard distributions, moments and moment-generating functions,
laws of large numbers and the central limit theorem.

name: Textile Apparel Ind
description:
Textile and apparel industries including fashion theory, production,
distribution, and consumption of textile goods.

name: Business Writing
description:
Effective communication in and for organizations, including businesses
(corporations), government agencies, and non-profit organizations. Suitable
for students entering careers that require substantial communications, such as
management, public relations, and grant writing.
prereq: UWP 001 or ENL 003; Or the equivalent and upper division standing.

name: Academic Literacies
description:
Composition, the essay, paragraph structure, diction, and related topics.
Frequent writing assignments.

name: Introd Textiles
description:
Introduction to the structure and properties of textiles. Consumer use and
fabric characteristics are emphasized.

name: Legal Writing
description:
Advanced principles of critical thinking, argumentation, and style, with
special emphasis on their application in the legal profession. Suitable for
students planning careers in law, business, administration, or management.
prereq: UWP 001 or ENL 003; Or the equivalent and upper division standing.

name: Physical Activities
description:
Physical Education Activities classes offered in the following areas:
aquatics, personal fitness, martial arts, individual sports, and team sports.
These academic classes are instructional rather than recreational and are
intended to improve activity specific skills and knowledge.

name: Writing in Bio Sci
description: Advanced instruction in writing in biology.
prereq: UWP 001 or ENL 003; Or the equivalent and upper division standing.

name: Elementrary Spanish
description:
Continuation of SPA 001 or SPA 001S in the areas of grammar and basic language
skills. Hybrid format combining classroom instruction with technologically
based materials.

name: Accel Calculus
description:
Accelerated treatment of material from MAT 021A and MAT 021B, with detailed
presentation of theory, definitions, and proofs, and treatment of
computational aspects of calculus at a condensed but sophisticated level.
prereq:
Grade of B or higher in both semesters of high school calculus or a score of 4
or higher on the Advanced Placement Calculus AB exam, and obtaining the
required score on the Precalculus Diagnostic Examination and its trigonometric
component.

name: Lab: Early Childhood
description:
Application of theories of learning and development to interaction with
infants, toddlers, and preschoolers at Early Childhood Laboratory. Applied
skills in communication, guidance and curriculum.
prereq:
HDE 140 { can be concurrent }; and Consent of Instructor. HDE 140 must be
taken concurrently for first 3 units of credit; students must contact the
Center for Child & Family Studies to enroll.

name: Applied Stat in Ag Sci
description:
Application of statistical methods to design and analysis of research trials
for plant, animal, behavioral, nutritional, and consumer sciences. Basic
concepts and statistical methods are presented in lectures, laboratories
emphasize data processing techniques, problem solving, and interpretation in
specialized fields.

name: World History 1350-1850
description:
Major topics in world history from the 14th century to the beginning of the
19th century. Topics will vary but may include: oceans as systems of human
communication and conflict; the global consequences of "industrious
revolutions" in Europe and Asia, etc.

name: Calculus
description:
Functions, limits, continuity. Slope and derivative. Differentiation of
algebraic and transcendental functions. Applications to motion, natural
growth, graphing, extrema of a function. Differentials. L'Hopital's rule.
prereq:
Two years of high school algebra, plane geometry, plane trigonometry, and
analytical geometry, and satisfying the Mathematics Placement Requirement.

name: Intl Grad Student ESL
description:
Multi-skills ESL course designed to help international/ESL students improve
their English language skills for successful academic study. Emphasis on
writing, speaking, listening, reading, and academic culture.
prereq:
Admission by placement examination or consent of coordinator; open to
international and ESL graduate students and limited status international
undergraduates (Education Abroad Program participants).

name: Human Rights and Gender
description:
Gender and sexuality in the context of human rights. Topics include women's
participation in the public sphere, the right to change gender, the right for
family privacy, and the right to marriage.

name: Intro Technocult Studies
description:
Contemporary developments in the fine and performing arts, media arts, digital
arts, and literature as they relate to technological and scientific practices.

name: Internship
description:
Work experience off and on campus in all subject areas offered in the
department. Internships supervised by a member of the faculty.
prereq: Consent of Instructor. Completion of 84 units.

name: Physical Activities
description:
Physical Education Activities classes offered in the following areas:
aquatics, personal fitness, martial arts, individual sports, and team sports.
These academic classes are instructional rather than recreational and are
intended to improve activity specific skills and knowledge.

name: Intrmed Multiling Wrtng
description:
Reading and writing short multi-paragraph texts for academic purposes.
Suitable for students whose primary home language was not English.

name: Writing in Health Prof
description:
Advanced expository writing common in the health professions, emphasizing
effective communication between the writer and different audiences. Topics
relate to health, disability, and disease. Suitable for students planning
careers in professions such as medicine, dentistry, physical therapy,
optometry.
prereq: UWP 001 or ENL 003; Or the equivalent and upper division standing.

name: Advancd Multiling Wrtng
description:
Reading and writing source/research-based texts for academic purposes.
Suitable for students whose primary home language was not English.

name: Calculus for BioSci
description:
Introduction to differential calculus via applications in biology and
medicine. Limits, derivatives of polynomials, trigonometric, and exponential
functions, graphing, applications of the derivative to biology and medicine.
prereq:
Two years of high school algebra, plane geometry, plane trigonometry, and
analytical geometry, and satisfying the Mathematics Placement Requirement.

name: Ethnographies of Japan
description:
Focuses on ethnographic writing about Japan. Includes modern scholarly
ethnographies, travel writing, blog posts, etc. Critical analysis of how the
Japanese ‚Äúother‚Äù is represented across time.

name: Env Chng Dis & Pub Hlth
description:
Analysis of environmental changes from pre-history to the present and their
influence on disease distribution, virulence and public health. Focus on
critical study of many human-driven environmental changes and the accelerated
transformation/spread of pathogens under globalization.

name: Eur Intel 1920-1970
description:
European thought and culture since World War I. Coverage includes: literature
and politics; Communism and Western Marxism; Fascism; Existentialism;
Structuralism; Feminism. Particular attention to Lenin, Brecht, Hitler,
Sartre, Camus, Beckett, Marcuse, Foucault, Woolf and de Beauvoir.

name: Middle East 1401-1730
description:
Middle Eastern history from the foundation of the Ottoman Empire on the
borderlands of Byzantine Anatolia through its expansion into Europe, Asia, and
Africa, creating a new cultural synthesis including the Arab, Greek, Islamic,
Mongol, Persian, Slavic, and Turkish traditions.

name: Tactical Leadership
description:
Small unit tactical operations serve as the basis for enhancement of
leadership performance through tactical application. Assessment of leadership
attributes, skills, and actions through participation in a variety of
leadership roles in problem-solving exercises.
prereq: MSC 131; or Consent of Instructor. Upper division standing.

name: Readings in Latin Prose
description:
Review of Latin morphology, grammar, and vocabulary. Readings in prose
authors, including Julius Caesar.

name: Global Social Change
description:
Introduction to change and diversity in world history, including the United
States. Examines population and family, technological change and economic
development, power and status, culture and identity.

name: Intro Linguistics
description: Introduction to the study of language; its nature, diversity, and structure.

name: Spanish Composition I
description:
Development of writing skills by way of reading, discussion, and analysis of
authentic materials, literary texts, and videos. Selective review of grammar.
Composition, journals, individual and group projects.
prereq: SPA 022 or SPA 022S or SPA 022V or SPA 022Y

name: College Writing-SCC157E
description: Not available.

name: College Writing-SCC157P
description: Not available.

name: College Writing-SCC157E
description: Not available.

name: Writing in Science
description:
Writing abstracts, research proposals, scientific papers, other forms of
scientific communication. Presenting data graphically. Primarily for students
engaged in or planning careers in basic or applied research.
prereq:
UWP 001 or ENL 003; Or the equivalent and upper division standing or
enrollment in a graduate science curriculum.

name: Academic Literacies
description:
Composition, the essay, paragraph structure, diction, and related topics.
Frequent writing assignments.

name: Intrmed Multiling Wrtng
description:
Reading and writing short multi-paragraph texts for academic purposes.
Suitable for students whose primary home language was not English.

name: Writing in Health Prof
description:
Advanced expository writing common in the health professions, emphasizing
effective communication between the writer and different audiences. Topics
relate to health, disability, and disease. Suitable for students planning
careers in professions such as medicine, dentistry, physical therapy,
optometry.
prereq: UWP 001 or ENL 003; Or the equivalent and upper division standing.

name: Writing Social Justice
description:
Advanced instruction in writing for Social Justice, using an interdisciplinary
approach combining feminist, critical race, ethnic, cultural, and
transnational studies; practice in techniques of research and styles of
communication for diverse audiences. Suitable for activists in community
organizing, non-profits, politics.
prereq: UWP 001; Or the equivalent and upper division standing.

name: Style in the Essay
description:
Style, language, and structure in the essay. Analyzing style, developing a
voice in writing, revising sentences, developing effective paragraphs and
arguments, and writing with force and clarity.
prereq: UWP 001 or ENL 003; Or the equivalent.

name: Intrmed Multiling Wrtng
description:
Reading and writing short multi-paragraph texts for academic purposes.
Suitable for students whose primary home language was not English.

name: Business Writing
description:
Effective communication in and for organizations, including businesses
(corporations), government agencies, and non-profit organizations. Suitable
for students entering careers that require substantial communications, such as
management, public relations, and grant writing.
prereq: UWP 001 or ENL 003; Or the equivalent and upper division standing.

name: Intrmed Multiling Wrtng
description:
Reading and writing short multi-paragraph texts for academic purposes.
Suitable for students whose primary home language was not English.

name: Vine Pests/Diseases
description:
Various pests and diseases of vineyards throughout California. Pest/disease
identification and control methods (to include sampling techniques) also will
be discussed. Integrated management approach to pest control methods will be
emphasized.

name: Lab Biol Cons Fishes
description:
Morphology, taxonomy, conservation, and identification of marine and
freshwater fishes with emphasis on California species.
prereq: WFC 120 { can be concurrent }; and Consent of Instructor.

name: Bas Cnpt/Pol Thry
description:
Analysis of such concepts as the individual, community, liberty, equality,
justice, and natural law as developed in the works of the major political
philosophers.

name: Russian Composition
description:
Practice in writing Russian. One composition on a different topic each week.
Topics include: history, geography, politics, and literature of Russia;
comparison of Russian and American lifestyles; current events. Conducted in
Russian.

name: Numerical Analysis
description:
Error analysis, approximation, interpolation, numerical differentiation and
integration. Programming in language such as Pascal, Fortran, or BASIC
required.

name: Res Method Human Develop
description:
Scientific process, research designs, and experimental controls; APA
manuscript style and scientific writing; statistical analysis and
interpretation of results. Laboratory exercises to collect data, analyze and
interpret results, and write scientific papers.
prereq: STA 013 or STA 013V or EDU 114 or PSC 041 or (SOC 046A, SOC 046B)

name: Elementary Spanish
description:
Introduction to Spanish grammar and development of all language skills in a
cultural context with special emphasis on communication.

name: The Criminal Justice Sys
description:
Sociological analysis of the different components of the criminal justice
system including the emergence and interpretation of criminal laws, the
contemporary roles and functions of the police, criminal courts and
correctional institutions.

name: Human Microbiology
description:
Biology of microorganisms that form commensal, mutualistic, and pathogenic
relationships with human beings, emphasizing their phylogeny, physiology,
genetics, and ecology. Effects on human nutrition, development and physiology.
Mechanisms of pathogenesis, immune response evasion, antibiotic action, and
antibiotic resistance.

name: NA Performance & Culture
description:
Interdisciplinary study of public expressive forms among Native Americans.
Comparison and analysis of music, dances, rituals, and dramas from throughout
North, Central, and South America in their social and cultural contexts.
Extensive film viewing.
prereq:
Upper division standing in division of humanities or social sciences or
consent of instructor.

name: Applied Statistics
description:
Descriptive statistics; probability; random variables; expectation; binomial,
normal, Poisson, other univariate distributions; joint distributions; sampling
distributions, central limit theorem; properties of estimators; linear
combinations of random variables; testing and estimation; Minitab computing
package.
prereq: (STA 013 or STA 032 or STA 100); (MAT 016B or MAT 017B or MAT 021B)

name: Physiology Dis
description:
Discussion of problems and applications relating to principles presented in
PHY 111. Problems assigned weekly showing novel applications of principles
described in PHY 111; repare answers to be delivered orally during the class
period.
prereq: PLB 111 { can be concurrent }; PLB 111 required concurrently.

name: Bas Cnpt/Pol Thry
description:
Analysis of such concepts as the individual, community, liberty, equality,
justice, and natural law as developed in the works of the major political
philosophers.

name: Intro Multiling Writing
description:
Reading and writing paragraphs and short multi-paragraph texts for academic
purposes. Suitable for students whose primary home language was not English.

name: Writing in Education
description:
Advanced expository writing in the contemporary American classroom. Strongly
recommended for teaching credential candidates.
prereq: UWP 001 or ENL 003; Or the equivalent and upper division standing.

name: College Writing-SCC157S
description: Not available.

name: Ethics Issues
description:
Presents challenging, contemporary ethical issues from a multi-cultural
perspective. Rotating topics will include Ethical Eating, Capital Punishment,
Euthanasia, Poverty, and Animal Rights.

name: Logic, Probability & AI
description:
Introduction to theoretical artificial intelligence with a focus on
nonmonotonic logic, Bayesian networks, and learning theory.

name: Advanced Composition
description:
Instruction in advanced principles of expository writing. Writing tasks within
and beyond the University. Different writing modes, including narrative,
analysis, explanation, argument, critique.
prereq: UWP 001 or ENL 003; Or the equivalent and upper division standing.

name: Advancd Multiling Wrtng
description:
Reading and writing source/research-based texts for academic purposes.
Suitable for students whose primary home language was not English.

name: Intro To Fem Theory
description:
Introduction to the emergence of feminist theory and to key concepts in
feminist theorizing. Examination of past and current debates over sexuality,
race, identity politics, and the social construction of womens experience.
prereq: WMS 050 recommended or consent of instructor.

name: Real Analysis
description:
Functions, limits of functions, continuity and uniform continuity, sequences
of functions, series of real numbers, series of functions, power series.

name: Intro to NA Lit
description:
Intensive focus on analysis of Native American literary texts, with frequent
writing assignments to develop critical thinking and composition skills.

name: Earth Materials Intro
description:
Physical and chemical properties of rocks, minerals and other earth materials;
structure and composition of rock-forming minerals; formation of minerals by
precipitation from silicate liquids and aqueous fluids and by solid state
transformations.
prereq: CHE 002A; (MAT 016A or MAT 017A or MAT 021A); (GEL 001 or GEL 050, GEL 050L)

name: Modern Algebra
description:
Basic concepts of groups, symmetries of the plane. Emphasis on the techniques
used in the proof of the ideas (Lemmas, Theorems, etc.) developing these
concepts. Precise thinking, proof writing, and the ability to deal with
abstraction.

name: Calculus for BioSci
description:
Introduction to differential calculus via applications in biology and
medicine. Limits, derivatives of polynomials, trigonometric, and exponential
functions, graphing, applications of the derivative to biology and medicine.
prereq:
Two years of high school algebra, plane geometry, plane trigonometry, and
analytical geometry, and satisfying the Mathematics Placement Requirement.

name: Work-Learn Vet Sci
description: Supervised work experience in reproduction.
prereq: Approval of project prior to period of internship by faculty sponsor.

name: Ag Nature & Society
description:
Multiple perspectives and connections between natural sciences, social
sciences, and agriculture. Emphasizes agriculture's central position between
nature and society and its key role in our search for a productive, lasting
and hospitable environment. Several full-period field trips provide hands-on
learning.

name: First-Year Seminar
description:
Investigation of a special topic through shared readings, discussions, written
assignments, term papers, and special activities (such as fieldwork, site
visits, laboratory work, etc.). Emphasis placed upon student participation in
learning. Students may take more than one First-Year Seminar, but may not take
more than one in any given quarter.

name: Healthful Living
description:
Application of scientific and empirical knowledge to personal, family, and
community health problems.

name: Trad Japanese Drama
description:
Survey in English of Japanese drama, focusing on traditional forms: noh,
ky√¥gen, bunraku puppet theater, and kabuki, with some attention to modern
theater. Texts of plays and secondary works on performance techniques and the
composition of plays.

name: The Chinese Revolution
description:
Analysis of China's cultural and political transformation from Confucian
empire into Communist state. Emphasis on emergence and triumph of peasant
revolutionary strategy (to 1949), with some attention to its implications for
post-revolutionary culture and politics.

name: Business Writing
description:
Effective communication in and for organizations, including businesses
(corporations), government agencies, and non-profit organizations. Suitable
for students entering careers that require substantial communications, such as
management, public relations, and grant writing.
prereq: UWP 001 or ENL 003; Or the equivalent and upper division standing.

name: College Writing-SCC157S
description: Not available.

name: Advanced Composition
description:
Instruction in advanced principles of expository writing. Writing tasks within
and beyond the University. Different writing modes, including narrative,
analysis, explanation, argument, critique.
prereq: UWP 001 or ENL 003; Or the equivalent and upper division standing.

name: Mushroom, Mold, Society
description:
Fungi as organisms with which humans interact daily, societal issues arising
from these interactions. Fungi in medicine, religion, agriculture, and
industry, as well as cultural perceptions of fungi.

name: Academic Literacies
description:
Composition, the essay, paragraph structure, diction, and related topics.
Frequent writing assignments.

name: Animals/Human Cult Disc
description: Small group discussions and preparation of short papers for HUM 004.
prereq: HUM 004 { can be concurrent }; HUM 004 required concurrently.

name: Trees & Forests
description:
Biological structure and function of trees as organisms; understanding of
forests as communities and as ecosystems; use of forests by humans; tree
phenology, photosynthesis, respiration, soil processes, life histories,
dormancy, forest biodiversity, and agroforestry.

name: Physical Activities
description:
Physical Education Activities classes offered in the following areas:
aquatics, personal fitness, martial arts, individual sports, and team sports.
These academic classes are instructional rather than recreational and are
intended to improve activity specific skills and knowledge.

name: Coaching Effectiveness
description:
Synthesis and application of basic components of sport psychology, sport
pedagogy, and sport physiology and basic management and administration of
athletics in public high schools.
prereq: Upper division standing; 3 units of PHE 001 and PHE 006 combined.

name: Paleobiology Lab
description:
Exercises in determining the ecological functions and evolution of
individuals, populations, and communities of fossil organisms in field and
laboratory.
prereq: (GEL 003, GEL 003L) or BIS 002B; GEL 107 { can be concurrent }

name: First-Year Seminar
description:
Investigation of a special topic through shared readings, discussions, written
assignments, term papers, and special activities (such as fieldwork, site
visits, laboratory work, etc.). Emphasis placed upon student participation in
learning. Students may take more than one First-Year Seminar, but may not take
more than one in any given quarter.

name: Population
description:
Introduction to the study of human population, including theories and
statistical measures; social causes and consequences of population trends;
changes in population structure; geographical distribution, migration,
sociopsychological factors affecting fertility.

name: Young Children
description:
Integration of research, theory and practice in child development, emphasizing
the role of relationships in creating a growth-promoting environment for young
children. Includes: peer relationships, emotional understanding and self
regulation, attachment, communication and school readiness.
prereq:
HDE 100A; HDE 140L { can be concurrent }; and Consent of Instructor. HDE 140L
required concurrently.

name: Physical Activities
description:

These academic classes are instructional rather than recreational and are
intended to improve activity specific skills and knowledge.

description:
Investigation of a special topic through shared readings, discussions, written
assignments, term papers, and special activities (such as fieldwork, site
visits, laboratory work, etc.). Emphasis placed upon student participation in
learning. Students may take more than one First-Year Seminar, but may not take
more than one in any given quarter.

name: Intro Microbiology
description:
Essentials of microbial biology, emphasizing phylogeny, physiology, genetics,
ecology, and pathogenesis. Interactions with other microbes, humans, and the
biosphere. Uses of microbes in agriculture and biotechnology. May be taught
abroad.
prereq: (BIS 001A or BIS 002A); CHE 002B { can be concurrent }

name: Human Memory
description:
Consideration of major theories of human learning and memory with critical
examination of relevant experimental data.
prereq: PSC 001; PSC 041; (STA 013 or STA 100); or Consent of Instructor.

name: Writing in Health Prof
description:
Advanced expository writing common in the health professions, emphasizing
effective communication between the writer and different audiences. Topics
relate to health, disability, and disease. Suitable for students planning
careers in professions such as medicine, dentistry, physical therapy,
optometry.
prereq: UWP 001 or ENL 003; Or the equivalent and upper division standing.

description:
Reading and writing source/research-based texts for academic purposes.
Suitable for students whose primary home language was not English.

description: Advanced instruction in writing in history.

prereq: UWP 001 or ENL 003; Or the equivalent and upper division standing.

description:
Study of Mexican culture through a diversity of cultural expression, including
elite, popular and mass media culture. Focus on national icons and archetypes,
multiculturalism, transnationalism.

Reading and writing short multi-paragraph texts for academic purposes.

name: Analysis Musts & Wines
description:
Fundamental principles of analytical chemistry as they relate to specific
methods used in winemaking.
prereq:
CHE 002C; CHE 008B; AMR 021; Or equivalent to any course. Students enrolled in
the lecture only portion of the course will be required to enroll in 1.0 unit
of VEN 199/ VEN 299.

description:

and beyond the University. Different writing modes, including narrative,
analysis, explanation, argument, critique.
prereq: UWP 001 or ENL 003; Or the equivalent and upper division standing.

Reading and writing source/research-based texts for academic purposes.

name: Writing/Visual Rhetoric
description:
Introduction to writing needs, conventions, and genres in design contexts.
Emphasis on applying critical reading, analysis, and writing skills to
designed products, such as graphics, visual communications, and clothes, and
designed spaces, such as exhibitions and interior architecture.

name: Gender & Race Experience
description:
Exploration of the co-construction of ‚Äúrace‚Äù and gender in comparative
national historical contexts and contemporary lived experience. Study of
intersections of race and gender in identities and how institutions, labor
migration, social movements and consumption shape racialized gendered
identities.

name: Number Theory
description:
Divisibility and related topics, diophantine equations, selected topics from
the theory of prime numbers. Designed to serve as preparation for the more
rigorous upper division courses.

name: Chamber Music
description:
Open to any student in the University whose proficiency meets the requirements
of concert performance. Study, rehearsal, and performance of ensemble music
for strings, winds, voice, piano, harpsichord, and organ.
prereq: Consent of Instructor. Admission by audition.

name: Intro to Brewing & Beer
description:
Basic description of brewing and associated processes, from raw materials to
final product; history of brewing and brewing science; types of beer
worldwide; world beer markets; basics of beer quality, including
wholesomeness; role of scientist in brewing.

name: Internship Pub Aff
description:
Supervised internship and study in political, governmental, or related
organizations.
prereq:

name: Groundwater Hydrology
description:
Fundamentals of groundwater flow and contaminant hydrology. Occurrence,
distribution, and movement of groundwater. Well-flow systems. Aquifer tests.

quality assessment. Agricultural threats to groundwater quality: fertilizers,
pesticides, salts.

name: Raisin/Table Grapes
description:
Overview of the raisin and table grape industries in California and other
production areas of the world. Cultural practices associated with raisin and
table grape production will also be discussed.

name: Exp Digital Cinema I
description:
Experimental approaches to the making of film and video in the age of digital
technologies. Builds upon foundation provided by course 20. Instruction in
technical, conceptual, creative, and critical skills for taking a project from
idea to fruition.
prereq:
CTS 020 or ART 012 or TCS 007B; TCS 170B; or equivalent with consent of
instructor.

name: Principles Pharm & Tox
description:
Online course provides training in core concepts of pharmacological and
toxicological sciences and prepares to develop higher-order problem solving
and critical thinking skills. Designed for advanced undergraduate students
with interests in pursuing graduate degrees in pharmacology, toxicology,
physiological sciences, and for students with an interest in pursuing D.V.M.,
M.D., Pharmacy, Dentistry and Nursing professional degrees. Students who
pursue careers in environmental sciences, public health management, and
epidemiology may also benefit from the subject matter presented in this
course.
prereq:
Consent of Instructor. Upper division standing in a science major; chemistry
through organic chemistry, general biology, or consent of instructor; good
standing with the university; computing capability (use MS Word¬Æ, Excel¬Æ,
PowerPoint¬Æ, menu driven software programs, Course LMS); own a computer or
have ready access to a computer with broadband Internet access; NPB 101 and
BIS 104 recommended.

name: Elementary Statistics
description:

Student's t, and chi-square distributions. Hypothesis testing and confidence
intervals for one and two means and proportions. Regression.
prereq: Two years of high school algebra or Mathematics D.

description:

Practical applications of soil biological diversity are emphasized.

interpreted in weekly lab reports; includes student-designed independent
project and written report.
